FAOTPRIES BILL.Memorandum by the Home Secretary.I circulate to my colleagues a revised draft of the Factories Bill, As they are aware, it has been announced that the Government intend to pass this Bill into law next Session, and a promise has been given that it would be introduced this Session in time to allow of its examination by the parties interested, and to give an opportunity for consultation in regard to it, in the Autumn. Recently in reply to a Question in the House I stated that I hoped to introduce the Bill this month.The Bill has been thoroughly examined by the Home Affairs Committee and, in its bearing on the work and interests of the Government Departments, by an Inter-Departmental Committee, and the only question which remains unsettled is as to the provisions to be inserted in the Bill for the regulation! of the hours of employment of women and young persons. When this question was under discussion last year, .it was complicated by considerations in regard to its bearing on the general question of the 8-hour day and 48-hour week. That question, however, has been set aside for the time being, and the question of the regulation of the hours of women and young persons in factories has therefore to be dealt with as one of factory administration, that is, it has to be regarded from the point of view of the protection of women and young persons employed in industry, The position is as follows. The statutory hours allowed by the existing Acts are 10 daily and weeklyfor textile factories, and IOf daily and 60 weekly, with overtime in addition in certain industries, for non-textile factories. These hours were regarded in many quarters before the war as too long, and a movement towards the shortening of the hours had already begun. This movement received a considerable accession of strength from the experience of the war. At the present time in the great majority of cases women and young persons are normally working not more than 48 hours a week, though they can and do work additional hours (within the special statutory limit of 60) when necessary.The Labour Government, in the Bill which they introduced in 1924, proposed to limit the hours of women and young persons in factories to 9 in the day and 48 in the week, with only a limited amount of overtime for certain classes of industry which are subjected from time to time to exceptional pressure of work.After thinking over the whole question very carefully, i put forward for the consideration of my colleagues the proposals which appear in Chapter 6, particularly clauses 66 and 67, of the revised draft.The retention in the Bill of tha hours laid down by the existing Factory Acts is of course out of the question. The assimilation of textile and non-textile factories, which have hitherto had different regulations as to the hours of employ-ment will in any case make that course impossible. i think it is clear too, that it will be very difficult, and from the political point of view unwise, to insert a scheme of hours of employment in the Bill which is markedly less favourable to women and young persons than the arrangements as to hours under which they are actually working. The cry has already been raised in connection with the mining problem that the Government are attacking the existing hours of work, and the cry will be renewed with greatly increased vigour and probably much greater effect on public opinion if anything like the existing statutory hours are retained in the Factories Bill.i accordingly recommend that the Government should propose in the Factories Bill to lay down for women and young persons hours of employment which correspond to the existing conditions, in other words, to prescribe a 48-hour week with a Mi:liberal provision as to overtime for all classes of factories and for young persons as well as for women, which will enable employers to adjust the hours of employment to meet the pressure of work. The number of permissible hours of overtime employment which I have inserted in the Bill is 100, with a maximum limit of 6 hours overtime in one week. These figures of course are subject to reconsideration. 100 hours overtime in the year means on the average an additional 2 hours a week and raises the average total of hours of employment per week to 50. If my colleagues, think a greater elasticity is desirable in the case of industries which are subject from time to time to exceptional rushes of work, I shall be disposed to agree and to recommend that in order to meet such cases, the Secretary of State should be given power to allow additional hours - at any rate for women and young persons over 16 - up to a maximum, say, of 150 in the case of particular industries which are specially subject to periods of pressure and in which the circumstances seem to him to justify it. A provision of this sort would correspond to the existing overtime provisions in the Factory Act of 1901 (sections 49 and 50)*It might also be desirable to give a general power of suspending the operation of the hours provisions in the Bm and of substituting other provisions in grave economic crisis involving national danger.These provisions, with the other provisions in the Bin such as the clause continuing the two-shift system, would I hope be sufficient to give industry all the elasticity it needs in arranging the hours of work for women and young persons, and at the same time to satisfy the desires of a very-considerable number, both in our own Party and in the country at large, who desire to see a real step forward taken in the improvement of the conditions under which aur women and young persons work in the factories of the country. ISth July, 1926.Unless this done, I am afraid that the Government will lose much of the credit which ought to come to it from the passing of the new Factory Bill, and that the passage of the Bill itself may be rendered much more difficult.W.J.H.
